title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
1 point earned for correct M and M2+

1 point for the correct concentration of M2+ (Zn2+)

Electrons flow from the anode to the cathode in a voltaic electrochemical cell. The anode is where oxidation occurs, and in the reaction above, Zn(s) is oxidized. So, the anode electrode must be Zn (M) and the solution contains Zn2+ (M2+). The [Zn2+] = 1.0 M in a standard cell. Additionally, the reduction potential for the Zn2+/Zn redox couple is less than that for Ni2+/Ni.
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

1 point earned for correct M and M2+

1 point for the correct concentration of M2+ (Zn2+)

Additionally, the reduction potential for the Zn2+/Zn redox couple is less than that for Ni2+/Ni.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
1 point earned for labeling the cathode in the cell diagram

1 point earned for the half-reaction

The cathode is Ni(s) , indicated by “X”

The half-reaction is 2e– + Ni2+ → Ni(s) .
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

1 point earned for labeling the cathode in the cell diagram

1 point earned for the half-reaction

The half-reaction is 2e– + Ni2+ → Ni(s) .

The student response earns two of the following points:

The half-reaction is 2e– + Ni2+ → Ni(s) .

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 point earned for indicating that Ecell increases (is larger)

1 point earned for recognizing that Q < 1 and/or that the term RT nF ln [ Zn 2 + ] [ Ni 2 + ] must be added to the Eo

Ecell = E° – RT nF ln [ Zn 2 + ] [ Ni 2 + ]

When the [Zn2+] is lowered to 0.100 M, then Q < 1. The value of the cell potential under these nonstandard conditions is more positive than E° (under standard conditions). The cell voltage increases.

An argument involving LeChâtelier’s principle is also acceptable: the decreased [Zn2+] increases the “potential” for the reaction to proceed to the right.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
1 point earned for the effect

1 point earned for the explanation

The cell voltage drops to zero when the salt bridge is removed.

This happens because the salt bridge is needed to allow charge balance to occur in the solutions the electrodes are immersed in. In the absence of the salt bridge, ions cannot flow to balance the buildup of cations in the anode compartment and the buildup of anions in the cathode compartment.
descriptions:
